title: Queen drummer Roger Taylor hits back at Bohemian Rhapsody critics
text:
Richard’s got too much money from this movie to care about the haters (Picture: Getty/20th Century)

Queen drummer Roger Taylor has hit back at criticism about Queen biopic Bohemian Rhapsody and called the reviews ‘superficial’.

The 70-year-old believes critics have ‘lost the essence of joy’ after watching movie after movie while criticising them.

He told Planet Rock: ‘There were many that were kinda sneering and superficial. I thought, “You just don’t get it, do you?”

‘You weren’t moved, and whatever, but f**k you actually. F**k you all the way to the bank, actually.’

The movie had Rami Malek win an Oscar for best actor for his role as Freddie Mercury.

‘Bad reviews usually mean that it’s going to be really successful,’ Roger continued. ‘I think people know a lot more than film critics, and the word of mouth via social media is so much more powerful than review from a guy who probably watches 40 movies a week, and has probably lost the essence of the joy of a movie.’

Bohemian Rhapsody made a whopping $903 million (£700 million) at the worldwide box office, and that already was an amazing feat.

The resemblance is uncanny (Picture: 20th Century Fox/Moviestore/REX)

Critics thought the movie was too predictable (Picture: Richard E. Aaron/Redferns)

The movie doing well didn’t stop Roger from holding a grudge against the critics who deemed the movie as predictable and typical.

Predictable? We would hope so.

At least Roger isn’t seething with anger on his own.

Guitarist Brian May mentioned how he found the criticism of the movie – which had a 49 out of 100 on Metacritic – ‘deeply disturbing’.

‘I found the public activity behind the whole awards season, and the behaviour of the media writers surrounding it, deeply disturbing,’ he said. ‘Vitriol and dishonesty, and blatant attempts to shame and influence the members into voting the way they, in their arrogance required them to.

‘It’s not the fault of the awards panels – they stood up well. It’s a kind of vindictive sickness that seems to have gripped public life.’

Audience reviews have been a lot better than critic ones, which is usually expected in this type of movie.

The bipic focused more on their music than Freddie’s illness (Picture: A Bailey/20th Century Fox/Kobal/REX)

One critic said: ‘Bohemian Rhapsody is a soulless, predictable, conventional and emotionally extortive musical biopic, although it’s all hidden behind the songs and musical sequences.’

Meanwhile, one viewer wrote: ‘The music of Queen is such a collection of hits that this alone makes for a good time, but the movie is visually appealing as well.

‘Rami Malek is fantastic along with the rest of the crew, good direction by Bryan Singer. This movie takes you on a wild ride right by the bands side, I loved the insight into their journey as a band.’
